ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is an excellent introductory survey to the major players in early modern philosophy. While no course can be totally exhaustive, MDR does a wonderful job presenting the main thinkers, their respective contributions, and their disagreements for the period.

I learned about the views of ten modern philosophers on gods existence and nature, perception, causation, necessity, skepticism, the mind-body problem, etc., and how to write a philosophy paper. I gained an introductory understanding of the modern history of philosophy and the skill of critically engaging with philosophical arguments.
history of early modern philosophy and all areas of philosophy, writing philosophy paper
Philosophical analysis, evaluation and comparison of arguments, philosophy paper writing
Learned a lot about metaphysics, epistemology, and the views of many of the most famous philosophers in the western cannon.

Really interesting viewpoints of early modern philosophers on a variety of topics as well as a few central themes (mind-body problem, causation, idealism, etc). It was also my first philosophy class, so I learned how philosopher papers differ from other academic writing.
An overview of modern philosophy from Descartes to Kant

The primary skill I learned was how to analyze and pull apart arguments. Some of the philosophers' arguments seem far fetched, but difficult to outright disprove. Learning how to pull apart the arguments and find detrimental weaknesses is a skill I will likely use forever.
The philosophical systems of Descartes, Malebranche, Spinoza, Conway, Leibniz, du Chatalet, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant. Writing philosophical papers and breaking down philosophical arguments.

The course covers key analytic philosophers of the early modern era: Descartes (and his correspondence with Princess Elisabeth), Malebranche, Spinoza, Conway, Leibniz, Du Chatelet, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, and Kant, and their views on topics that are still relevant and discussed today: skepticism, the mind-body problem, causation, determinism, necessitarianism, idealism, etc. Students will get to see and interact with very clever arguments for very unintuitive and strange conclusions regarding these topics. And while the conclusions are strange, its unclear where the argument goes wrong. Thus, students will learn how to reason about philosophical arguments, pick them apart, and support/object to them. Moreover, students will learn the importance of interpreting the purpose and content of philosophical arguments and ideas with considerable charity.
A broad overview of about 10 philosophers focusing on ideas of causation, mind and body, substances. Wrote 2 papers.
I learned how to read many pages (although the reading load wasn't too bad) of philosophical text while picking out the more important bits.
The metaphysical systems of important early modern philosophers. How to write a clear philosophical argument and a strong philosophy paper.
Overview of early modern philosophy with an emphasis on the fault lines between rationalists and empiricists.

You learn about a bunch of different philosophers and their takes on God, God's existence, and the existence of a material world.
A lot of the topics are similar, with different nuances across the various philosophers.
early modern philosophy. This was just a good factual, functional, and thought process introduction to early modern philosophy.

Knowledge of the canon
Skills in philosophical analysis
Continuiites in philosophical thought
I gained a solid grounding in the philosophers covered
Learned a lot about modern philosophy

By taking this course, not only have I learned more about modern philosophers (like Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Hume, or Kant) but I also improved my reasoning and critical thinking skills. This course really encouraged me to push the limits of my understanding and apprehend philosophy in a way that is my own. My TA pushed me to question the philosophers' perspectives and made the course more enjoyable overall/
A good basis in modern philosophy

This was my first philosophy class and my first experience writing philosophy papers. This class taught me how to write in a concise and direct way. It also taught me how to think about ethics in a mathematical way. I relearned how to think, read, and write through the lens of philosophy.

Knowledge: the early modern tradition in philosophy - major figures, positions, arguments, motivations, and implications on several key issues (mostly epistemology and metaphysics)
Skills: close reading of difficult texts, reconstruction and evaluation of arguments
Insights: history of philosophy is a worthwhile endeavor. As a skeptic of broad survey courses usually, i became convinced that every aspiring philosopher should this class as soon as possible. You can't fully understand what people mean without knowing who they're responding to and what they're aiming to prove, and this course teaches you exactly how to make the most of these things to charitably interpret complex arguments and philosophical systems.
Breadth of knowledge of important ideas of philosophers from the early modern period.
Metaphysics, Causality, Perception, Idealism, Determinism and Free Will, etc
A great overview of early modern philosophy. Builds a substantial toolkit to tackle problems of epistemology and metaphysics.
History of early modern philosophers.
I got a solid general overview of 10 major philosophers from this time period. It was an interesting introduction to reading and writing about philosophy.

Insight into early modern philosophical inquiry

Dualism, monism, proofs of God's existence, metaphysics, etc
I learned about early modern era philosophy.

Through this course, I learned about the history and the philosophy of the European rationalists. I developed a picture of the evolution of this philosophical thought and the historical forces that interacted with it. I learned how to break down philosophical arguments and the logical techniques used to argue philosophical claims. I learned about the issues that are central to metaphysics, include panpsychism, pantheism, determinism, necessitarianism, induction, and causation. I am coming away from this course with a solid foundation to understand the origins of many modern philosophical schools of thought.
A wide-ranging survey on a dozen or so philosophers in the Early Modern period, presented in comparison with each other on primarily metaphysical and epistemological views.

Metaphysics
Clear definition and analysis of arguments
How to understand philosophy and logic and how to go into thought experiments. Critical thinking skills.
Philosophy
All about modern philosophy, understanding their arguments and evaluating them to some degree.
I learned much about early modern philosophers systems of metaphysics
really fun reading about different philosophers
I learned a lot about modern philosophy, specifically by Descartes, Spinoza, Hume, and Kant, among others.
I learned how to think deeply and conceptually about difficult concepts, in addition to being able to articulate ideas in writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Perhaps moving each of the essays back two-weeks to allow more of a turnaround time at the end of the course? It felt like we went right from essay 2 to final preparation with little time to look at our grades. I also know that this creates a lot more work for TFs, but I think a rewrite option on at least on essay one (and preferably essay two as well) where either the two grades are averaged or the better one is granted in full would really help demystify philosophical writing in this intro course.

Strengths: interesting lectures, brilliant professor, fascinating discussions in weekly section, well-explained content, wide range of choices for paper prompts
Weaknesses: There's disparity in how TFs conduct their sections, which is not inherently bad but when it comes to writing your paper, you're going to want to talk directly to your specific TF about your approach and what you can do to improve since that TF will be grading yours.

strengths: wonderful overview of major authors
improved: more Kant!

The course by nature has to move very quickly which is a strength because we got through a lot of content, but also a weakness because we could not go as in depth into the arguments/full ideologies off the thinkers as I sometimes would have liked.
Professor Della Rocca is a great lecturer. He has well structured lectures but leaves space for questions and interactions with students during lecture.

Strengths - MDR is a wonderful lecturer and even better in office hours; also an extremely kind and approachable professor; references to Olivia Rodrigo and Taylor Swift were a highlight of his teaching style
This is an exceptional course. I think removing one philosopher and spending more time on the rest would make this course much better.

Professor Della Rocca and my TA were definitely the strengths of the course. MDR is an absolutely incredible lecturer and is one of the leading authorities in the field. It was an honor to have taken his class and despite his high status, he still knew most of the class by name and was super engaging at office hours. The content was also super interesting to me and I felt like I learned more in this class than any other class at Yale. I cannot think of any weaknesses.
MDR is great and his energy is infectious, wish we related metaphysics to more relevant real world issues/thought experiments though.
Section could have been more engaging. Preparing for the final exam was initially a little stressful.

Strengths: very clear lectures and accessible staff
Cons: Sections didn't leave time for student opinions on the material.

i wish there was longer discussion time in sections beyond the 50 minutes. most of it is spent reiterating any of the confusing points and it is then difficult to transition into flow of philosophical conversation because so much of the material is dense and needs clarity. lectures are phenomenal and define points really well, but then the lectures and readings dont always time well with section so not everyone is on the same page or we are discussing different things in section to soon before or much time after they were covered in lecture

Strengths: Amazing professor and TFs. Office hours are so helpful and insightful. MDR's lectures are so good that you could probably complete most of this course without the readings. Numerous resources are given to help you learn to write a cogent philosophy paper (which is strikingly different from papers in other disciplines). Weaknesses: Only went over the metaphysical systems of early modern philosophers, when the name of the course would suggest a broader scope of content.
It would be great if the required course for the philosophy major on "modern philosophy" encompassed more than early modern, rationalist thought.

Strengths:
- MDR's lectures are amazing, so easy to follow and understand. I didn't do most of the readings, but his lectures are more than sufficient for the whole course, to be honest.
- MDR is just an amazing professor
- My TF was amazing. She is leaving but was absolutely wonderful. Very knowledgeable, understanding, and intelligent. 
- Low workload

Weakness:
- Grading across Section TFs wasn't consistent. My friend's paper was rushed and pretty average, and he still somehow got an A- whereas another friend (who had a much better paper IMO) got a B. Since papers are 30% of your grade, it can affect your grade pretty heavily. 
- Study Guides or more notes would help
- Sections can feel a bit disorganized

Strengths:
- great course

Improvement:
- maybe more time for papers?

Professor was great
Structure was clear
I found it comprehensive but sometimes wished I could delve deeper on a single philosophical concept

Very good lecturer 
Could be clearer about expectations

The lectures are very entertaining and never boring. The professor does a great job at conveying difficult philosophical topics in an approachable and sometimes witty manner. I think that the course could be much more powerful if lecture met three times (instead of twice) a week.
Perhaps uniformity among ta handouts
The class was very well organized and extremely engaging. I always felt like I could follow the lecture and he explained everything to the perfect extent. I cannot think of any improvements.

fantastic course as both an introduction to philosophy and a survey of the early modern period and several extremely interesting issues (skepticism, mind body interaction, existence of God), nothing to improve on imo

Strengths: MDR as a professor. He explains things really well so that not quite getting the reading the first time through is not a barrier to understanding and enjoying the material. Makes a huge difference in my opinion 

Weaknesses: because there were so many philosophers to get through, we didnt get very deep into their ideas or arguments besides the topics you specifically chose for papers. But thats to be expected in an intro course
Professor Della Rocca is a very engaging and thoughtful professor, which made the class great.
could talk about the connections between philosophers throughout the course instead of individuals.

This course can be as boring or interesting as you decide it is. I found the material most stimulating when I was last-minute cramming for the final or writing my papers, honestly, because it forced me to really immerse myself in the material.

Strengths -- loved the material & instruction
Weaknesses -- wish there were more resources on Canva, e.g. lecture outlines...would make exam review a bit easier, especially given how abstract the material could get
Readings not as structured as they could be.

This was a strong course. The readings were accessible and manageable. The grading was more than fair, and I received helpful comments on my papers. The peer community for this course was strong, and I frequently studied and talked about the material with friends. The only weakness I can think of is that there were only two graded assignments the entire semester, in addition to the final exam. My skills at writing a philosophy paper improved throughout the semester, and it would have been great to have more opportunities to develop this skill, and not to have the grade depending so heavily on a few assignments.
It's just a great course!

Strengths: final was good, papers were good
Weaknesses: midterm would be helpful, perhaps some supplemental texts to clarify the readings
My section was really dry and wish it was more argument and debate focused.
Strength: incredible teaching of content by MDR, very interesting content, readings are not too long. Few weaknesses
Very insightful and well-taught. Wish the sections were more engaging.

This is a good foundational course in philosophy; it covers a wide range of philosophers. Professor Della Rocca was a great professor, always explaining topics very well. I wouldn't say this class has any weaknesses. I just personally didn't love the material but that has nothing to do with the class itself.
This course was well organized, and I specifically liked the handouts which made following lecture and reviewing the final easy.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Philosophy major or not, you will find yourself engaging with the ideas brought up in this course.

Yes, it is a very interesting introduction to Philosophy. Some concepts might seem very blurry and difficult, but Professor Della Rocca does a great job in breaking them down to facilitate student undertsanding.
absolutely
I would to someone interested in philosophy and/or considering a philosophy major. Otherwise I think it might be a lot of work without any engagement.
Absolutely. Professor is very knowledgeable, engaging, and funny. Material is often deep and definitely makes you think.

Yes! It was definitely my favorite class of the year. MDR is an incredible professor who keeps lectures engaging and breaks down complicated philosophical concepts in a very digestible way (you could honestly get by without doing any of the readings because he explains things so well). The content is truly very interesting and thought-provoking, and the workload is super manageable. It's a great introduction to philosophy that never felt overwhelming. I honestly can't recommend this class enough for anyone who is remotely interested in philosophy and the topics in this course.

Absolutely - if you want an accessible, fun introduction to analytical philosophy with a great professor, this is a good class.

Note that it very heavy on metaphysics so not for those looking for a class on ethics, or philosophizing about the meaning of life/death. This is about understanding various intellectual systems and learning to reconstruct these arguments.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. This was my first real interaction with philosophy and the material learned in this class can be applied to many other topics. I found it to be incredibly engaging and I will take more philosophy classes because of it.

I absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in philosophy, or wants to branch out/fulfill a distributional requirement. I learned so much about the subject of philosophy, as well as writing papers and reading difficult texts.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to any student who is interested in philosophy. The ideas discussed form the foundation of much of contemporary philosophy, so they are helpful in understanding more modern ideas. Moreover, the arguments put forth by early modern philosophers are extremely interesting, especially with regard to how reason is used to justify odd conclusions. Its really interesting to see how philosophers respond to each other and build off of each others ideas.
Yes, I think you get more out of the course if you do readings and participate more in section.
Yes, but I would say that I recommend seminar-style philosophy courses over this.
i would, but it helps to know/have a grasp on the writing of philosophy papers before going into ittheres a bit of a learning curve there.

Yes, as long as you're aware that the real title of this course should be "Introduction to Early Modern Metaphysics," and especially if it's taught by MDR (who is a legend and who holds really insightful office hours).
Yes! Learning philosophy is super important. How could you graduate from Yale without ever learning about the ideas of essential philosophers?
If you're interested in Philosophy, 100%. Prof Della Rocca is a great lecturer and can explain difficult philosophical readings in an accessible way.

Yes if:
You are interested in learning and reading a lot about God and different arguments for God's existence. 
If you're looking for a Credit/D/Fail class, this is perfect.

No if:
If you are interested about something more specific in philosophy -- ethics or epistemology etc -- there are other classes that may be better.
Yes! Very interesting to learn!
Yeah it's a good overview
I would for those who are considering a philosophy major
Yes its a good introduction to philosophy
Yes, absolutely! This was one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. Even if you are not a philosophy major, I think this course will help you consider things from a new perspective.
MDR is so good. only take with MDR
Yes! I loved this course

Yes. This class gives a great sense of what it is like to learn philosophy and gives a real sense into what the topic entails. While the readings are challenging, the lectures are very clear and engaging.
Absolutely. Good for philosophy gourmets at any level
I really enjoyed it, to be fair Im a philosophy major. I recommend it if you like philosophy and want to get a solid foundation, the content of this course would certainly be important for that
Yes! It is an accessible but stimulating philosophy course.
This course would definitely be an excellent fit for anyone, with or without a backing in philosophy.
If theyre interested in the philosophers in the syllabus.

yes, if philosophy is your jam, particularly philosophy concerning the veracity of the material world and God, as well as our own selves and how our mind and body communicate. Not much talk of moral philosophy, and much of the philosophy is based on God's veracity, so if that sort of thing doesn't interest you I wouldn't take this course.
Definitely. Especially if you're in the CogSci or philosophy majors!
Yes
Absolutely. It's a fantastic course, even for non-philosophers.

Maybe.

If interested in metaphysics. Also quality of course depends highly on the TA.

Yes if you want a comprehensive and manageable overview of modern philosophers. It does not go too deep, but professor does a very good job of ensuring you have a solid understanding of basic philosophical arguments.
Yes
Absolutely. I learned so much. MDR is an absolute legend. TAKE!
Yes! Modern philosophy is fascinating and MDR is a one of a kind man and instructor.
Id recommend this course if you really like metaphysics.
Yes, very fun!

If you're curious or interested about philosophy, then this is certainly a great class to take. I think it's a good intro class, delving deep into a lot of different philosophers with many different opinions about the world. However, if you're not really into philosophical thinking (especially from way back when) then maybe pass and look for a different class.
Yes, I would recommend to anyone who is considering the philosophy major.
